subject: Extend live-migration-force-complete to use postcopy if available
commit_message:
Extend live-migration-force-complete to use postcopy if available

Since QEMU 2.5 and Libvirt 1.3.3 it is possible to use postcopy
live migration to ensure an upper limit in the amount of memory
to be transferred duing the live migration process. This option
enables to live migrate instances with memory-intensive workloads
by driving the migration process by the destination host, i.e.,
after the switch to postcopy mode, the destination VM is the active
one and therefore any dirty pages are directly generated at the
destination hosts. This patch ensures that force-complete will use
postcopy instead of pausing the VM during the migration is postcopy
is available and enabled.

Partially-implements: blueprint auto-live-migration-completion

Change-Id: Ic27f10682024ad6fee7d433f47e84aeeaa55120b
Signed-off-by: Luis Tomas <luis5tb@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Mark port as ready after enabling dhcp at agent

When subnet is created and network is scheduled to dhcp agent, the
dhcp agent will request neutron server to create dhcp port.

Neutron server will create and mark port as BUILD and wait for the
ready signal from dhcp agent.

that the dhcp port is ready. So, the reported bug can be observed.

not mark ports as 'ready' as there is no network cache. This patch also
marks all ports in network as ready, in case that happens.

subject: Perform additional disable_service checks
commit_message:
Perform additional disable_service checks

With the advent of plugins and their settings files it has become
possible to disable_service in local.conf only to have the service
re-enabled in a plugin settings file. This happens because of
processing order.

To get around this the disable_service function now aggregates
service names into a DISABLED_SERVICES variable which is then checked
during enable_service. If something tries to enable something that
was previously disabled, a warning is produced in the log and the
service is not enabled.

Then after all configuration has been sourced a final check is to
done by verify_disabled_services to confirm that something has not
manually adjusted ENABLED_SERVICES to overcome a previously called
disable_service. If something has, the stack dies with an error.

Change-Id: I0f9403f44ed2fe693a46cd02486bd94043ce6b1a
Closes-Bug: #1504304

subject: Allow virtuals during python-setuptools install
commit_message:
Allow virtuals during python-setuptools install

On CentOS7 the python-setuptools package has been obsoleted in favor of
the python2-setuptools package. Attempting to install python-setuptools on
CentOS7 using Puppet results in a package always being installed [1], which
breaks tests which run Puppet twice to check that nothing changes. This is
fixed by providing an allow_virtual parameter [2].

[1] $ sudo puppet apply -t -e 'package {"python-setuptools": ensure =>
installed }'
Notice: /Stage[main]/Main/Package[python-setuptools]/ensure: created
$ echo $?
2

$ sudo puppet apply -t -e 'package {"python-setuptools": ensure =>
installed }'
Notice: /Stage[main]/Main/Package[python-setuptools]/ensure: created
$ echo $?
2

[2] $ sudo puppet apply -t -e 'package {"python-setuptools": ensure =>
installed, allow_virtual => true }'
Notice: /Stage[main]/Main/Package[python-setuptools]/ensure: created
$ echo $?
2

$ sudo puppet apply -t -e 'package {"python-setuptools": ensure =>
installed, allow_virtual => true }'
$ echo $?
0

Change-Id: I50ade953d4c71c9d52214199629ada59f04ea575

subject: Return snapshot_id in os-assisted-volume-snapshots POST
commit_message:
Return snapshot_id in os-assisted-volume-snapshots POST

os-assisted-volume-snapshots POST API is used to create
snapshot of volumes on backends such as NFS or GlusterFS
by storing data as qcow2 files on these volumes.

NOTE- This API is only used by Cinder.

This API's request accept "snapshot_id" and optional "id"
in create_info object.
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/assisted_volume_snapshots.py#L27-L36

and return "id" in response which is nothing but the "id" sent
in create_info during request.
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/api.py#L3453

But this returned "id" seems meaningless as this is/can not be used anywhere.
 - Delete operation requires "snapshot_id" (which can be different than "id").
 - Cinder store the snapshot info with "snapshot_id" not with "id" sent during
   create_info in POST API.

This seems like just return back the input id which is not being
considered anywhere.

So if anyone create snapshot via this API and use returned "id" for
delete or any other operation then, it is going to be wrong input id.
And end up with obsolete status on Cinder side:
 - delete operation is done using qcow2 file name not by input id. So no issue.
 - But during delete operation, libvirt driver try to update snapshot
   status in cinder which will throw exception as it would not find the
   snapshot (in this case, Nova just log the exception).

As of now, it does not create any issue on Cinder side as "id" is not
being passed/used there.

Second issue is if "id" is not being passed in request then POST API's respone
will have "id" as None which does not seems good response.

It make sense if POST API return the create_info["snapshot_id"]
instead of create_info["id"] which can be used meaningfully.

NOTE- There is no change is API response fields, it change the
value returned in attribute "id".

Change-Id: Ibd76b31b79461db2313d0fca269c685fcee9448b

subject: on-delete cascade rule for resource_data
commit_message:
on-delete cascade rule for resource_data

During deleting of resource, the resource_data is also loaded in memory
and then deleted. This is not performant. The passive_delete option in
relationship deletes the relation without loading the children. This
patch configures the resource to have a passive-delete relationship with
resource_data and configures ondelete CASCADE so that the DB takes care
of deleting the resource_data when a resource is deleted.

This patch proposes the following changes:
- When deleting a resource do not load resource_data.
- When a resource is deleted, DB takes care of deleting resource_data.

The resource data remains intact when the FK constraints are deleted and
added to reflect on-delete cascade.

subject: Remove DictCompat from InstanceAction
commit_message:
Remove DictCompat from InstanceAction

This change removes NovaObjectDictCompat from the InstanceAction and
InstanceActionEvent objects. Changes were made from dict syntax to use
dot syntax or getattr/setattr. The API tests were also updated to mock
out the compute api instead of the db api. This allowed the mocks to
return objects (as the API would), instead of db model dictionaries.

New private methods were made in the API tests to compare an
action/event with a given request. These were compared prior using key
deletion and dictionary equality. Now, because these are using objects,
it was changed over to new methods, which borrow from o.vo's compare_obj
fixture, which is used to compare objects to a dictionary.

Within fake_server_actions, there were events and actions that were
stored as dictionaries. These were to be returned by the DB, so
dictionaries are still valid for those. An objectified version of those
dictionaries were also added, which are meant to be returned by the
compute API.

The cells' compute InstanceActionAPI also needed to be changed over.
Originally, the api was taking in dicts from RPC and passing them back
from the API. Now, the API is changed to convert the primitives it
receives from the RPC API into objects.

subject: Detach volume after deleting instance with no host
commit_message:
Detach volume after deleting instance with no host

If an instance is booted from a volume, shelved, and goes into an error
state due to some reason, the volume from which instance is booted
remains even the instance is deleted because instance has no host
associated with it.

Called _local_delete() to detach volume and destroy bdm if instance is
in shelved_offloaded state or has no host associated with it. This will
cleanup both volumes and the networks.

Note:
Ankit had submitted same patch [1] earlier which was reverted [2] due
to a race condition on jenkins if an instance is deleted when it is in
building state.  The patch was then rebumitted [3] fixing the
the failure of race condition by reverting the ObjectActionError
exception handling in _delete.  This patch was later re-reverted [4]
due to continued jenkins race conditions.

The current patch avoids the jenkins race condition by leaving the flow
for instances in the BUILDING state unchanged and only calling
_local_delete() on instances in the shelved_offloaded or error states
when the instance has no host associated with it.  This addresses the
concerns of the referenced bugs.

[1] Ic630ae7d026a9697afec46ac9ea40aea0f5b5ffb

subject: libvirt: virtuozzo instance resize support
commit_message:
libvirt: virtuozzo instance resize support

Adapt "nova resize" code to support Virtuozzo ploop disks.
As far as ploop disks are in fact directories we add '-r' argument
to all utilities that deal with instance' disks such as cp, rsync and scp.
Thus we copy disks universally whether they are folders or files.

Also using "prl_disk_tool" instead of "qemu-img" is better for ploop images
because it resizes guest filesystem as well.

We can't resize disks from guest OS in containers,
because they are not allowed to write directly to block device.
ploop tool can resize partition table and internal filesystem,
but only for container's disks. Such disks must have only one partition
with ext filesystem.

prl_disk_tool can resize disks with internal filesystems
and doesn't require any special layout so it can resize disks
for virtual machines.  So it's better to use this tool instead of ploop.

Also we make compute.filters more strict
We call "ploop" only with "restore-descriptor" argument
And we set disk size in megabytes for prl_disk_tool

Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Guryanov <dguryanov@parallels.com>
